stem: The patient's EKG shows ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, indicating a possible inferior wall myocardial infarction. The priority intervention is to administer oxygen and prepare for {}.

mnemonic.mnemonicMeaning: Morphine, Oxygen, Nitroglycerin, Aspirin - Beta-blockers, ACE Inhibitors, Statin, Heparin (Standard initial treatment for acute coronary syndrome)

rationale.incorrect: Administration of intravenous fluids. While maintaining adequate hydration is important, the priority in an acute MI is to restore blood flow to the heart.

questionTrap.trapReason: Intravenous fluids are a routine part of general care, but in the context of a heart attack, they are not the most pressing issue. The priority is intervention to reperfuse the heart.

clinicalPearls: ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF is indicative of an inferior wall MI, which is often associated with right ventricular involvement.
Time is muscle. Rapid intervention is crucial in minimizing myocardial damage during an MI.

itemContext.sbar:
07:00 S: Mr. Jones, a 62-year-old male, reports severe, crushing chest pain that began approximately one hour ago. He rates the pain as 8/10. 

07:02 B: Mr. Jones has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily and Atorvastatin 40mg daily. He has a penicillin allergy. 

07:05 A: The 12-lead EKG reveals ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Oxygen is administered via nasal cannula at 2L/min. Vital signs are: BP 90/60 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, RR 24, SpO2 92%. 

07:10 R: I recommend immediate cardiology consult for emergent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) due to the suspected inferior wall MI. Prepare for administration of aspirin and nitroglycerin per protocol.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:

07:02 B: Mr. Jones has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily and Atorvastatin 40mg daily. He has a penicillin allergy. 

07:05 A: The 12-lead EKG reveals ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Oxygen is administered via nasal cannula at 2L/min. Vital signs are: BP 90/60 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, RR 24, SpO2 92%. 

07:10 R: I recommend immediate cardiology consult for emergent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) due to the suspected inferior wall MI. Prepare for administration of aspirin and nitroglycerin per protocol.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
BP: 90/60 mmHg
HR: 110 bpm
RR: 24
SpO2: 92%
Temp: 98.6°F (37°C)

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content:
Troponin I: 8.0 ng/mL (Elevated)
CK-MB: 25 U/L (Elevated)
Potassium: 4.0 mEq/L
Sodium: 140 mEq/L
Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content: Chest X-Ray: No acute abnormalities noted.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Lisinopril 20mg daily
Atorvastatin 40mg daily
Oxygen 2L/min via nasal cannula
